abstract.t: This document presents an enhanced control plane for Ethernet VPN (EVPN) that eliminates the need for data plane flooding of ARP/ND messages. EVPN enables hosts to communicate within the same subnet, and the current EVPN E-LAN solution relies on data plane flooding for IP address resolution. This proposed solution aims to reduce flooding and optimize communication in large-scale networks.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 and RFC 8174.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Ethernet VPN (EVPN) solutions, as defined in , facilitate communication between connected endpoints (CE) or hosts that share the same subnet. This communication utilizes broadcast and multicast forwarding, also known as flooding, which is a common behavior in Layer-2 networks. However, this flooding behavior can pose challenges for some providers, leading to unpredictable patterns and increased bandwidth consumption in their networks. Moreover, it may expose security risks, potentially enabling malicious users to launch DDoS attacks.

While has made significant progress in reducing flooding over EVPN networks through ARP/ND proxy behavior, certain aspects remain unresolved. The initial sign of life messaging when a CE/host connects to the network is not addressed. Intra-subnet communication relies on neighbor discovery protocols (ARP/ND), where ARP requests and Neighbor Solicitation (NS) messages are flooded across the Layer-2 core network to all remote devices connected to that subnet.

Unfortunately, in a large-scale network, this flood of three or more broadcast/multicast messages from CE/hosts to discover remote CE/hosts can lead to unpredictable flooding storms. Some deployments resort to provisioning static ARP/ND entries to mitigate this behavior. However, maintaining such a list of static entries proves to be costly and cumbersome, especially when adding or removing new CE/hosts.

dl.dd: The term request is widely used in this document. It refers to ARP request for IPv4 or ND solicitation for IPv6.

section.title: Address Resolution Solution
section.t: This document proposes a new solution extending the EVPN control-plane where the IP address resolution is performed from control-plane rather than data-plane. The procedure leverages ARP/ND proxy capabilities as described in . The following section describes the behaviour to perform ARP resolution. Neighbor Discovery Protocol works in a similar manner.
This picture shows a simple layer-2 network where a common subnet is shared across CE1 and CE2. PE1 and PE2 support the new IP address resolution procedure.

In this example, CE1 initiates the communication with CE2 using ARP protocol. The new procedure is as follow:
CE1 sends ARP requests to PE1 with destination IP=IP2 and broadcast MAC address as destination address.
PE1 punts incoming ARP requests to control-plane. Data-plane floods these requests to all locally connected ACs (in the same broadcast domain) only and avoids the replication / flooding to any remote PEs over the L2 core.
PE1 learns the CE1 ARP request entry in control-plane to keep track of this request. PE1 creates a single new BGP-EVPN IP address resolution route, which is advertised to remote PEs (PE2). Basically, it requests all remote PEs to look for a specific IP address which may be connected for probing purpose.
PE2 receives a single IP address resolution route and triggers local CE2 ARP request to all locally connected ACs in the same broadcast domain. PE2 uses CE1 source MAC/IP per ARP request towards connected CEs for transparency. PE2 performs local probing for specific destination IP2 address. This becomes a local behaviour from PE2 point-of-view.
CE2 receives the ARP request and sends an ARP reply with its own information.
The reply may be punted to control-plane on PE2 where the new MAC_CE2 and IP_CE2 binding is created. The PE2 advertises to PE1 via existing EVPN RT2 (MAC+IP) the CE2 host information. CE2s ARP Reply may also be forwarded based on a lookup on the destination MAC address via the layer-2 data-plane.
PE1 may create local MAC/IP binding entry in control-plane based on received BGP EVPN RT-2. Based on the ARP request entry learned initially, PE1 creates an ARP reply message and send it to CE1. PE1 uses CE2_MAC + CE2_IP for this ARP reply. Optionally, a GARP may be transmitted in replacement of the ARP reply as recommended per when ARP proxy is in use.
PE1 marks the initial CE2 request as resolved in control-plane. The associated IP address resolution route advertised in BGP is withdrawn.

section.title: BGP EVPN Address Resolution Route
section.t:
The IP address resolution procedure requires a new BGP route in EVPN. The BGP EVPN NLRI as defined in is shown below:
+-----------------------------------+ | Route Type (1 octet) | +-----------------------------------+ | Length (1 octet) | +-----------------------------------+ | Route Type specific (variable) | +-----------------------------------+
BGP EVPN NLRI

This document defines an additional route type (TBD) in the IANA "EVPN Route Types" registry [EVPNRouteTypes] to be used for the advertisement of EVPN probing route:
Value: TBD
Description: IP Address Resolution
For backward interoperability, a node that does not recognize the route type TBD (RT-TBD) will ignore it.
The detailed encoding of this route and associated procedures are described in the following sections.

section.title: Address Resolution Encoding
section.t:
Where:
The Length field of the BGP EVPN NLRI for an EVPN IP Address Resolution route MUST be either 44 (if IPv4 addresses are carried) or 68 (if IPv6 addresses are carried). The source and destination IP prefixes MUST be from the same IP address family.
The Route Distinguisher (RD) and Ethernet Tag ID MUST be used as defined in . In particular, the RD is unique per MAC-VRF.
The Ethernet Segment Identifier may be a non-zero 10-octet identifier. It identifies the first-hop interface when an ESI is configured. The ESI format is described in .
The source MAC address is the one from the CE originating the IP address resolution request.
The destination MAC address is the one received from the request on the first-hop PE. It can either be set to broadcast MAC address or be set to a specific value when the PE is dealing with a unicast request.
The source IP prefix length can be set to a value between 0 and 32 (bits) for IPv4 and between 0 and 128 for IPv6, and it specifies the number of bits in the prefix. The value MUST NOT be greater than 128.
The source IP prefix is a 4- or 16-octet field (IPv4 or IPv6). The value is set to the source IP address of the originator of the request.
The destination IP prefix length can be set to a value between 0 and 32 (bits) for IPv4 and between 0 and 128 for IPv6, and it specifies the number of bits in the prefix. The value MUST NOT be greater than 128.
The destination IP prefix is a 4- or 16-octet field (IPv4 or IPv6). The value is set to the targeted IP address of the incoming request.

The RD, Ethernet Tag ID, source and destination MAC, source and destination IP prefix length and IP prefix are part of the route key used by BGP to compare routes. The rest of the fields are not part of the route key.

section.title: Considerations
section.t:
There are clear reasons for the usage of a new EVPN BGP route type to perform IP address resolution:
Possible prioritization of routes exchange between PE (importance of ARP/ND request/solicitation compare to other routes).
Specific manipulation over each IP address resolution request and response (security feature, RPL, etc.).
Usage of dedicate route reflector for scalability and performance to handle specifically any address resolution routes.
Backward interoperability with current machinery. For instance, the extension of RT-2 to achieve similar behaviour is inappropriate. Existing deployed routers may explicit use RT-2 routes for forwarding purpose only.
Provides behavioural transparency by carrying source host MAC and IP address to remote PEs.

section.title: Usage of ESI field
section.t: The ESI field is meaningful when CE/host is connected to multi-homed PE running all-active load-balancing mode. Its purpose is to avoid unnecessary probing towards the originating CE/host from where the initial request was sourced.

section.title: Originating Address
section.t: MAC address and IP address of the originating CE are transmitted as part of the new NLRI. They serve multiple purposes:

list.t: Allow remote PE to reconstruct the ARP/ND request packet as if it was received from the data-plane. The targeted CE won't notice the difference between control-plane based and data-plane based solutions.
Allow multiple CE/host to send ARP/ND request towards the same destination. Having the source MAC and IP has part of the NLRI key keep all routes unique.
Allow PE to provide security check over the source.

section.title: Rebuilding NS message on Egress PE
section.t: In the case of IPv6, the neighbor solicitation (NS) message MUST be built as specified in sections 4.3 and 7.2.2 for the address lookup NS message.
The Source IP address and the Link Layer Address in the SLLOA option MUST be set to the Source IP Prefix and the Source MAC address in the EVPN Address Resolution Route NLRI , respectively.

The target address MUST be set to the Destination IP Prefix field of the NLRI, and the IP destination address is solicited-node multicast address (SNMA) corresponding to the target address a mandated by .

The receiver is expected to use the SLLAO and not the source MAC to reply. At Layer-2, the source MAC MUST be that of the sender (this node). The receiver is expected to use the SLLAO and not the source MAC to build its neighbor cache entry (NCE). If the receiver is not compliant and uses the source MAC instead, this router will receive and route the packets from the receiver to the source IP.

The destination SHOULD be set to the multicast MAC address associated to the SNMA (see section 7 of for Ethernet, unless the source already knows a possible MAC address for the destination in which case, the unicast MAC MUST be tried first.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The mechanisms in this document use EVPN control-plane as defined in . Security considerations described in are equally applicable. This document uses MPLS and IP-based tunnel technologies to support data-plane transport. Security considerations described in and in are equally applicable.
